job_title: Covid-19 Contact Tracer in New York, NY
pros: Good hourly pay in comparison to most customer service/call center jobs. Different shifts available when you first sign up
cons: UHG went out of its way to avoid doing the right thing, not just cutting corners wherever it could but riding its employees like racehorses into the ground and shooting them when their knees gave out. First of all, it doesn't hire employees for Covid, but farms the job out to recruiters, so it's not responsible for them. I was hired as a contact tracer towars the end of July of '20 and when things got really heavy in the late fall some of my colleagues and I were trained to work with people who had Covid, not their contacts, which is a much more involved process--those people are called case investigators, and make at least $3 - $6 more per hour, nobody's willing to say--but the fact is we weren't given a raise. We deserved some kind of raise, and when we asked our recruiters for it were told they were busy hiring new people who would all be trained to do the same thing so they couldn't. It turned out to be only partly true, but the fact that UHG was unwilling to remunerate employees who they moved into a new position (without asking if we wanted the job)--they actually created a new job title for us, cross monitor--and expect us to work harder for them without complaining...I've had a couple of teammates get fired "for cause" all of a sudden after complaining that we were doing work we weren't hired for. And I mean suddenly, within 24 hours. Recently, due to the seemingly insurmountable surge, we've been told that we won't get paid for "unproductive" time, which means any time we're not literally on the phone. Researching someone's information before calling to make sure another family member wasn't just called 5 minutes ago? Unproductive. Writing a note for the next tracer letting them know that the child's mother couldn't finish the call because her other son was being discharged from the hospital, so please wait and call back in a couple of hours? Unproductive. Going to the bathroom when it's not one of your scheduled breaks? Definitely unproductive! We're working as hard as we can, we're not getting paid as much as we should for it, and we're getting talked to as if we're whipping boys. It's exhausting. In the last six months I know

review_title: Great place to work with one exception
pros: Great medical directors, managers and staff. Wonderful leadership. Open to employee feedback. Very fair salaries. Work at home options. Great benefit package with one exception. Excellent work culture.
cons: I absolutely loved my job and had planned to work at UHG until my full retirement age, unfortunately for health reasons I had to cut my career short by 3 years and go out on disablity. UHG has a great benefit package in all areas with the exception of their STD & LTD program. They outsource the management of disability to outside providers. The STD contracted provider is difficult to work with and in most cases will deny at the first level review however they do have a good appeals department with competent staff and fair medical directors and if the disability is legitimate they will approve on 1st appeal. That is not the case however with the LTD contract provider, they are governed by ERISA laws and know they do not need to be under any actual legal oversight and will fight any approvals, legitimate or not, if already approved by STD or not or if already approved by Social Security or not, they have hired their own MDs who do cherry picking and flat out bad faith denials and the disabled employee will be not only be sick but will be in the fight of their life trying to get approved for the LTD benefit and most often they will wear the employee down and force a settlement for pennies on the dollar. This company does not even open their case files for UHG HR review, they are self funded, they collect their own information, they hire their own doctors and they do their own denials, the employee has no right to jury trial or even a session before a judge under those ERISA laws and bad faith denials are the norm rather than the exception.

job_title: Nurse Practitioner in Des Moines, IA
pros:
no pros to this job- if u are an APP be prepared to not use your brain. the job is more focused on social worker issues-and coding 
not sure why they need APPs---it seems a social worker or RN is all they need to fulfill the role. management is only concerned about numbers and coding. this is a heavy coding job.
cons: no work life balance u will be charting until midnight. your work hours are 8am-midnight (that involves charting) management does not care that you are working into the evening. drive times are on average 1-2 hours one way. upon being hired I was told the work life balance would be great and that i would only have to drive far away (90milles one way 1/month). if you are ok with charting until 11pm + every night then this might be a good fit for you. also they expect you to call you patients 3x to confirm appointments you have to sell the program to get all your visits in (15 per week +) many patients do not answer the phone or are non compliant. it felt like a sales gig or social worker job (not criticizing social workers or RNs but if u are an APP be prepared not to use your skill set to the full extent)

pros: Pay is decent but the culture makes it. UNBEARABLE
cons:
Added review already that I will update asap with more details but wanted to add that their software is sooooo outdated and hinders the job. It’s truly AWFUL. You’ll be astounded.
Also many people have wanted to take their life or have been severely emotionally damaged due to the toxic abusive culture so far

pros: I liked that they had different insurance plans to choose from and days they provided lunch or breakfast.
cons: Patient care is last and lost. They hold on to people who are excessive call outs and want you to consistently perform the work of three people. They will make snide remarks like “well that’s going above and beyond which is part of your standard work” or “well we cannot let that person go because we are short staffed” The reason they are short staffed and have high turnover is BECAUSE they keep those who constantly call out. And when those people actually do show up? They don’t perform so you are still doing their work. Then comes raises and you think , okay I’m going to be recognized for my hard work.. but put on the face guard because the slap in the face is severe. Raises are not performance based. Bonuses are shared and not worth the hassle you endure by management and being overworked. Loyalty means nothing. Don’t plan on thinking this is a company you can stay and retire with. If it’s a first job, steer clear because it will destroy your confidence in the healthcare industry. I have seen high turnover before but nothing to this magnitude and has nothing to do with COVID.  The company bleeds of greed because they are too focused on profit and upper management and provider raises. I have an extremely positive attitude but they even penetrated my good nature by harassment, micro aggressions, passive aggressive attitudes, and carelessness. They treat you like your some sort of miracle worker that’s capable of things only God can do. This company caused lots of health and emotional distress. If you bring violations to the attention of higher ups they twist it around into a major drama and act like there is something wrong with you and will make you confront the person in violation to “work it out”. Ummm no nah uh. What’s to work out? I’m not the violator, the thief, the liar, the law breaker. So this results in you better keep your mouth shut and if you see something don’t you dare say something. The operations manager was petty, immature, unprofessional, and would try to divide the team, and was successful in team division. They operate on “it’s not my problem and not my fault”. You will spend an exhaustive amount of time reporting equipment malfunctions and 6 months later they decide to work on it and or address it. Then it works momentarily and breaks again. After awhile you give up and just drown. The clinic is not even half staffed and they add more work and have the audacity to question why work is not getting completed on time. It won’t matter  if you know what you doing, are skilled, have a solid work ethic. This is a sales position and they get all the commission.  We were told that the aforementioned is a perspective and therefore not reality. Excuse you but If it’s a collective perspective then it is in fact a reality.

pros:
I can only speak to my particular department but my pros are:
Full time work from home with an internet connection UHG pays for.
Good PTO, 401K, and stock options.
For now, my department seems to care about work/life balance. See my cons on why that might change.
My teammates are wonderful, capable people. I can count them as friends. I love working with them.
The work I do is meaningful and I do think I’m making a difference.
It seems like there are a lot of career opportunities if you’re able to apply for them.
cons:
Overall, the employee insurance plans stink. It’s baffling to me you can be an insurance company and offer such terrible plans to your own employees.

For my particular area:
There’s been too much change. We’ve had 5 different supervisors in a year and a half. Just when we start to learn our current sup’s management style they pull them away from us and assign us to someone else. We also have a great way we do our daily work and now they want to completely overhaul that as well - why? Have you ever heard if it’s not broke don’t fix it? We’ve been getting rave reviews from our business partners on the work we do but now they want to change all of that. They’re also not asking us current employees for any advice on this work program transition. We are the ones that do the work daily - wouldn’t you want our input?

Because of reason one we have had people fleeing my team as quickly as they can. And yet management (whoever is in charge that week) refuses to fill them timely. I have no idea why. They keep telling us people are coming but it hasn’t happened. I’m starting to believe it’s not going to happen.

Micromanagement is terrible. We are monitored on what’s happening on our computer screens and how much idle time we have in an hour. We are adults and we are getting our work completed, even on a skeleton crew, so why the need to babysit us? They say it’s for our own good and to help us with staffing but that can’t be true if we’ve been waiting for help for almost half a year.

job_title: Clinical Pharmacist in Sugar Land, TX
pros:
- Used to have a great office cohort. Shifted to work-at-home a few years before the pandemic, so we were prepared for the shift in workflow and attitudes.
- Great work-life balance with a standard M-F 8-5 schedule, plus working at home with its conveniences (for instance, not having to drive to work)
- Remote work after being with the company for some time. Being able to work in any of the 50 US states is nice.
- Interesting line of work, being more able to apply clinical knowledge as pharmacists and having the support and resources to do our best work.
- Various side projects to help enhance workflow and change up the everyday routine of case review.
cons:
- Not easy to be promoted due to employees lasting a long time and only so many supervisors per cohort of employees.
- Depending on your direct superior, you can be encouraged or discouraged in your professional development.
- Micromanagement, especially with time-tracking software, can be discouraging to employees who were trying to escape the "metrics" mindset from the community pharmacy setting.

job_title: Nurse Practitioner in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Excellent company to work for, great benefits, excellent compensation, 401k match, CME days and reimbursement competitive with industry standards. 
 However, many changes with the Coronavirus , making it not as an enjoyable experience as it once was: doing a lot more charting and pre-visit covid questionnaires-basically doing more with the same expectations and time allotted. Develop relationships with repeat clients, fulfilling to be able to actually spend time with your patients. Currently no prescribing, but that will be changing thanks to Coronavirus. Will be looking at doing mostly refills of maintenance meds, no narcotics or controlled substances😅.
cons: Archaic charting system, requiring many updates, and very slow, with patches and fixes that create other problems. Very redundant system. Cutting and pasting ad nauseam covid requirements and protocols. Slow computers and in home referrals can considerably lengthen the day. Definitely take my charting home with me every night I work, but it's not complex (no portal messages! ), but not like an urgent care when you walk out of the building and you're done. Also, must make confirmation calls night prior to in home visits, so does infringe on home life a little bit.

review_title: Less Earning and Less Learning but good Work life balance depending upon project.
pros:
1. Work life balance is good but it depends on the project. I guess WLB good for most of the project.
2. Job Security. :- I just saw 1 director or Sr. director laid off in USA. In India I never see any one got fired in last couple of years. Normally, it is difficult to find this info.
cons:
1. No much learning. Not a single learning platform is given like Udemy, Linkedin learning. What is given for learning is totally waste & not of use.
2. Mostly old outdated work/technology.
3. Mostly People are lazy/lethargic. May be due to good work life balance.
4. Huge variable pay. You get peanut in your in hand salary. Variable pay is paid once in a year. I never got full variable amount even with top performance rating.
5. No care for talent. Even you are too good, better than others & your seniors. You won't be promoted easily. They can just give you 10-15K of award recognition. That's all. But it will not matter for anyone how strong you are technically. Slowly you will start reducing your skills. You will become lazy like others. They/Manager sees your year of experience to promote you they won't check your talent. :D funny part.
6. Salary hike is very less. You will be mostly give avg. rating even if you are doing every thing, you are the only strong technically person. It doesn't matter, ratings are given like round robin. because no body evaluate actually. So mostly you will be getting 3 rating and 6% hike if your salary package is less than 15 LPA. I guess it will be 3-6% with 3 ratings if your package is high. Corona scenario was different every company was giving good hike.

Many good people work there and the work environment is generally positive. They have a large population of telecommuters and are willing to let employees work from home if business needs allow it.
cons: They don't value their employees contributions. Innovation and consistency are met with apathy. The compensation is below market value. Although they are an insurance company the health insurance benefits are poor. Middle Managers are overworked and underpaid but they generally do their best for their direct reports. Upper Management is disconnected. They will say the right things but rarely do they follow through with impactful changes to increase employee satisfaction.

pros:
- Generous amounts of PTO
- WFH / Flex work
- Cool offices if you care about that
- Free fizzy water.....
cons:
Pay raises and below market salary! Even if you're a high performer good luck getting more than 1.5% raises every year. I consistently got 4s and 5s and never got more than 1.7%. After 5 years in my tenure my wages adjusted for inflation were significantly less than when I started. Bonuses seemingly get smaller every year as the budget tightens.

For being the worlds largest health provider - our health insurance benefits are absolutely lacking. You would think this is the one thing UHG would try to get right with their employees but they are so crooked they cannot even offer us competitive health coverage. 

Corruption and nepotism - The part of this company I've worked in is so rotten with friend hires, family hires, and favoritism it would make 14th century feudal lords blush. The amount of people I've seen get SG 27, 28 and 29 positions just because they 'knew' someone is unpalatable. These are supposed to be subject matter experts in Networking and Cyber Security. However at UHG it seems anyone with a firm handshake and the right connections can get a six figure gig. 

Current leaders in my org are absolute sociopaths who think ruling by fear, mistrust, and public shaming is what it takes to drive success. Why do you hire highly skilled engineers if you do not trust them or want their advice?

review_title: Do yourself a favor, and DON'T
pros: I think Occupational Health and Safety employees mean well. Other than that, nothing. Zilch.
cons:
Recruiters will lie to you, hiring managers will lie to you - and, once you sign your employment contract, you're treated like absolute garbage. If you reach out to HR, you're bullied.

To start, they place you in the lowest paid position possible. Expect that pay to be $15 per hour (after tax, $11-$13). Benefits will cost you an additional $150-ish per paycheck. The "best" and "lowest deductible" health insurance policy is $1,400. I've had family policies with far lower deductibles, and MUCH better coverage. So, yet another proverbial strike. 

Don't be sold by the hiring bonus, please. There's a "clause" on it - that being, if you quit or are fired before 24 full months of employment, you get to pay that money back. That isn't a bonus, it's forcing employees to stay in a position they most likely are going to hate. For the record, Sales Support is selling insurance policies. You're going to have a ridiculous quota to make - you're not going to, so do not expect commission pay. OH, but do expect "mandatory" overtime. I'd love for someone to define what that actually means - last time I checked, overtime is considered voluntary. 

Tuition reimbursement - forget it. They control what classes you take, and if the classes are not directly related to your current position - expect to be denied by one of your (many) managers. 

You're filling a low paying position, with absolutely NO chance of advancement. Besides the tuition reimbursement scam, you're overworked - you have nothing left for self-care or improvement. Look online - plenty of former employees have claimed depression, anxiety, and insomnia. They will suck the life out of you - period. 

They care about one thing: generating revenue. If you're not, you're out.

pros: Stable outlook, many places to move within a large company. 28 days PTO to start.
cons: Super slow. Typical of large corporations, the smallest decisions require many many people and teams to weigh in before anything changes, constant team reorgs and many teams that are internally facing and add no real value. review_title: I say I would recommend to a friend - I would, but I would tell them all of these things.
pros:
There really are opportunities for growth here - I see a lot of reviews stating no one gets raises or promotions. I have been with the company 5 years, and in that time I have risen four pay grades and increased my earnings by 74%. So know that it's definitely possible to get good raises and get ahead, although it is also very challenging. How can you accomplish this? Be professional at work. Don't miss work without a good reason (try saving sick days for when you're REALLY sick). Work hard to make quality and production metrics. Be resourceful, accountable, and approach problems with solutions instead of complaints. Volunteer for extra projects when possible.

The incredibly structured and micro-managed atmosphere surrounding metrics actually makes it a true pay for performance environment. Your work speaks for itself. When your yearly review comes around, your supervisor has tangible data they are pulling from, and it's not just based on what they sort of think they remember you did over the last year or how hard you tried to get on their good side.

This a Fortune 14 company. UHG is EVERYWHERE. With much of the workforce telecommuting (either working for home or from an office reporting to different sites), a lot of boundaries are broken down, and in theory you have a wide variety of options for career movement that would not exist in most traditional company settings.

I have had incredible supervisors who have developed me and promoted my talents and strengths every step of the way.

UHG has very high expectations, and working there has prepared me well for so many of the challenges that any workplace could throw at me.

WAH opportunities abound for those who are interested.
cons:
It's not all flowery praise. I often question, long term, whether it's really healthy for me to continue to work at a place that causes me as much stress as this company has/can.

By far THE WORST health benefits I have had as a working adult in corporate America. We see what is offered in terms of plans. We are not getting a fair deal there, and every single person working there, bottom to top, knows it. UHG has some amazing healthcare plans available - just not for its employees.

There are so many departments with different rules, systems, and procedures that communication and issue resolution between internal business partners is a sad, complicated mess. Things are never streamlined. I do think they try, but they don't succeed.

Everything is about numbers, and at the end of the day, most people care less about if the numbers reflect accurate data, or if the data has simply been collected in a manner which makes it APPEAR that things are on target.

Talent Acquisition is a train wreck. There is up to a six month lag period in some of their systems (which no one will admit to, but is evident). I have been grilled by people on my ability to use MS Outlook (?????) who are just supposed to be validating my responses to the questions I answered online. Look, if I've been exceeding expectations on my performance reviews, I can probably use e-mail. I have had recruiters fail to set up interviews; if there are any issues, often the recruiters do not respond to e-mails, and CC'ing their supervisors doesn't do much either. Well after accepting a new position internally, I was still getting contacted by TA for interviews for positions I had removed myself from, and I was recently contacted to take a survey because they show I am applying for positions currently. (I have not applied for positions in at least five months.)

job_title: TELEPHONIC RN CASE MANAGER in Atlanta, GA
pros: Not having to commute to work.
cons:
I should have read reviews before I started here, but I will do this one favor for any nurses aspiring to work for UHG. This is a large company but the worst I have worked at my whole career as a nurse. Dept. had me as salaried but I had to take PTO for anything not work related, even if it is for 30 min, but as a salaried employee, I had to take PTO in 4 hour increments. No flex time or comp time were ever offered to me nor anyone I spoke to, for MD appts. or anything not work-related. Even as a salaried employee, I had to make up time. If working over I was told to log out on time and continue my task. From my experience, my dept. see Impossible metrics, made the job more like an assembly line of calls. My job was a strict call-center environment. Meeting metrics meant you not reading charts or prepping for calls. I sat in dialer all day taking cold calls like a customer service representative, with breaks and lunches clocked to the minute, with Immediate IMs from running behind on a call, causing break to run late. I couldn’t leave my desk while in dialer, not even to sign for a delivery, unless I got permission. I didn’t work to manage cases, I existed to staff the dialer. Literally, I could not get anything done even when it wasn’t my day to be in dialer for the harassment to go into dialer. No work/life balance, manager expected me to do work related things on my personal time, like applying for licenses and reading CEUs for other states over the weekend. Doesn’t matter that my license is compact. Only 5-10% of nurses of entire program were let off for one day, which made it very hard to be off for urgent needs unless I called out. The micromanagement is a beast at this place. I needed permission to do anything other than opening or closing cases. Trust me, the money isn’t worth it. The health insurance is the worst. I am convinced this is where nurses go to be broken.

I also planned to escape my dept. but found out the hard way that none of the jobs listed in job sites are actually eligible for internet transfer. The only jobs I saw open for internal transfer were the ones like mine, that no other nurses want. The turnover rate is so high here, you get constant case transfers from nurses quitting. Nurses are literally here one day and gone the next. This place also has an intense bully-type culture.

The pay is a little above-average, which is the only plus. I used it as a bargaining tool for my salary at my next employer.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: The Optum office itself was gorgeous. Great cafeteria, Caribou Coffee, convenience store, onsite health clinic, gym with nice locker rooms and covered parking. Overall they have a diverse group of workers and do seem to have a lot of older workers.
cons: Optum has a lot of jobs and the new corporate campus is amazing. That said, the culture was sad. Prepare yourself for a lonely existence where you spend most of your days at your desk on WebEx. Culturally the organization is made up of a lot of people who, once they've learned the company specifics, dig in and coast along with the status quo. It is not a friendly environment. New employees are basically hazed by the culture. If you don't understand terminology, technology or who does what, you are on your own. Even enrolling in your medical benefits is self-service, and they make the benefits! If you are in any of the Twin Cities offices, expect within the first few months to have a corporate sit-down with your boss questioning if you really want to work there and why you aren't committing 80 hour weeks. Eventually you start giving into the bureaucracy and plan your days around the least path of resistance. Externally, Optum is positioned as a youthful, innovative and modern company, but that is not that culture on the inside. I question their ability to attract and retain creative individuals. For the most part, the people you will deal with are bureaucratic bullies who have been there for years and do not want to change.

review_title: A good opportunity for the right people
job_title: Special Needs Family Advisor in Kingston, NY
pros: benefits, pay, paid holidays, bonuses & PTO
cons: This specific position within UHC requires a lot of training which is condensed into 16 weeks/4 months (at least for my class). I thought that would be more than enough time to learn and be comfortable in my position, but the truth is that you will never know absolutely everything and you have to be comfortable with that. You will be responsible for a lot of different issues and will need to know how to address it or at least know where to go for help if you're unsure. They have a great support system and lots of resources to help you on a day-to-day basis with customer calls, but it can be really stressful if you're someone who doesn't know how to handle that type of situation. Especially with the possibility of getting a call from a really upset customer, which of course happens in the insurance field. I'll be honest that I worried often between each call because I didn't want to get someone screaming (or sometimes cursing) and I may not know how to help their situation. I'd have to put them on hold so I could reach out to other resources and they DO NOT like that. You also have to be okay with change and be able to keep up with new information. Lastly, you have to be okay with being monitored. Since you work through the computer the company provides, you are also using systems that track your activity. You are responsible for governing yourself every day and if you're not doing a good job of that, you will absolutely get a message from a supervisor or manager. Sometimes they may ask "is everything okay?" or just flat out ask you why its taking you so long to do whatever it is you're doing. So. This job could honestly be a dream for someone who can handle this type of work environment. The Pros are really unlike most jobs and those alone make the job worth it. You just have to be the right type of person.

pros: Reasonable Pay, normally ample supplies, Well kept facilities
cons: Since UHG purchase have slowly and steadily reduced employee benefits. Before UHG purchase averaged 8-10 percent merit increases annually. After UHG purchase of med express average 1-1,5 % increase annually. No more than CPI. Monthly request days on schedule reduced from 7 to 5. Semi annual bonus used to average 2500-3000. After takeover less than 3k annually can be expected. Doors dont lock until 8pm (12 hour shift) and no patients turned away. If seven to ten sign in at 750 pm expect to work late an hour or more with no compensation. All providers are considered “exempt ie salary”. No overtime pay. 401k match reduced from 4 percent to 3.5. Annual CEU reimbursement reduced by 500-800 annually. Long mandatory teleconference scheduled before 8am or after 8pm with no compensation. Before UHG take over when supervisor asked for Practitioner to pick up extra shifts time and a half and often double time offered. Since UHG takeover supervisors rarely offer incentives to pick up extra. They expect you to be a “team player” and work extra shifts at straight time rate. Often clinics are short staffed of ancillary personnel ie nurses Med techs. Providers are expected to continue with their responsibilities and pick up responsibilities of short staffing ie triage patients, give injections ect. Overall, since UHG takeover, morale overall has significantly decrease due to above mentioned. Supervisors inform employees how well the Company overall and stock price is doing while at the same time UHG has taken away compensation and other employee incentives. UHG is a very large company with over 300k employees. Its very evident employees are not valued and you are nothing but another number that can be replaced. Nothing like Med Express used to be when owned by Mr Alderman who treated and rewarded all his employees like they were family.

review_title: I cannot wait to leave this place behind - stole 3+ years of my life
pros: Pros: I guess I made some money (more than I made elsewhere)
cons: The list is so long, it is hard to even know where to start. I worked in two different departments, and both were overworked, understaffed and had some of the worst issues with morale I have ever seen in 10+ years of my life. All the typical corporate crap: terrible work life balance, people taking 2+ week medical leaves because of the stress, anxiety and health issues UHC caused, dumping work on people before vacations, and a never-ending door of people leaving for better jobs. This place will SUCK THE SOUL OUT OF YOU. I truly believe I am a worse human being having worked for this place. I hear that it used to be a good place to work in the 90s and aughts, but that place is no more. They make their billions off the backs of the poor humans who have the misfortune of hoping for some semblance of the American dream, and every department is staffed by VPs whose sole qualification for becoming a VP is the fact that they are able to be sociopathic and narcissistic in the way they run the business. I have some unbelievable things at this company, and I only worked here 3+ years. It felt like a lifetime, and I know I will be paying the bills on the PTSD of the long hours I sacrificed - I go to counseling to deal with my issues with this place. Good luck all ye who choose to enter here. Better to turn around now.
